simulated_ratings.title: Sunless (Sans Soleil) (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: I was entranced by its meditative travelogue and found its reflections on memory haunting long after it ended

simulated_ratings.title: Harold and Maude (1971)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its morbid wit blossoming into a tender, life-affirming romance completely won me over

simulated_ratings.title: Birth of a Nation, The (1915)
simulated_ratings.feeling: I can acknowledge the historical technique yet felt overwhelmingly alienated and disturbed by its poisonous ideology

simulated_ratings.title: Fellini Satyricon (1969)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The wild, surreal pageantry fascinated me even as its episodic detours kept me emotionally at a distance

simulated_ratings.title: Garden of the Finzi-Continis, The (Giardino dei Finzi-Contini, Il) (1970)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its graceful melancholy and gathering historical dread moved me deeply

simulated_ratings.title: Female Trouble (1975)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bold and abrasive in spirit, it left me mixed—amused at times but not fully engaged

simulated_ratings.title: Wings of Desire (Himmel über Berlin, Der) (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its compassionate gaze and yearning romance felt sublime, rewarding a quiet, patient mood

simulated_ratings.title: How Green Was My Valley (1941)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A deeply heartfelt, nostalgic sweep that pulled me straight into its family’s joys and sorrows

simulated_ratings.title: Romeo and Juliet (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lush and immediate, the young lovers’ tragedy felt fresh and achingly beautiful

simulated_ratings.title: Woman Under the Influence, A (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Raw, intense, and compassionate, it impressed me even as its volatility was hard to sit with

simulated_ratings.title: Russian Ark (Russkiy Kovcheg) (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gliding through eras with dreamlike grace, it left me dazzled by history and atmosphere

simulated_ratings.title: Night, The (Notte, La) (1960)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense and humane, its wartime stakes and moral choices kept me absorbed

simulated_ratings.title: F for Fake (Vérités et mensonges) (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Playful and sly, its dance with truth and illusion delighted me

simulated_ratings.title: Brother from Another Planet, The (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle humor and sci‑fi whimsy made for a warm, offbeat urban fable

simulated_ratings.title: Freeway (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its grim fairy‑tale edge and relentless nastiness wore me down despite its nervy energy

simulated_ratings.title: Atalante, L' (1934)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, lyrical, and quietly magical—it left me glowing

simulated_ratings.title: Winnie the Pooh and the Blustery Day (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pure, gentle delight that whisked me back to childhood with its songs and simple wisdom

simulated_ratings.title: Salo, or The 120 Days of Sodom (Salò o le 120 giornate di Sodoma) (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its relentless cruelty left me repelled, with no meaningful engagement beyond revulsion

simulated_ratings.title: 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Awe‑inspiring and hypnotic, it satisfied my sense of wonder like few films do

simulated_ratings.title: Play Time (a.k.a. Playtime) (1967)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its graceful visual gags and modernist playfulness kept me grinning

simulated_ratings.title: Blow-Up (Blowup) (1966)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The stylish ambiguity intrigued me even if its cool detachment kept me just outside

simulated_ratings.title: Trouble Every Day (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The chilly fusion of desire and violence left me queasy more than moved

simulated_ratings.title: Romance (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its explicit, punishing exploration of intimacy pushed me away despite moments of honesty

simulated_ratings.title: Red Desert (Deserto rosso, Il) (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Industrial alienation and fragile emotion resonated with me, even if the mood is heavy

simulated_ratings.title: Revenge of the Pink Panther (1978)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A breezy, silly romp with enough inventive gags to keep me happily chuckling

simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest and sharp, its populist fable stirred me while still charming.

simulated_ratings.title: Auntie Mame (1958)

simulated_ratings.title: Pellet (Bola, El) (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tough yet tender, this coming-of-age tale earned my empathy.

simulated_ratings.title: Saturday Night Fever (1977)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Electric on the floor and bruised at heart, it felt vivid and alive.

simulated_ratings.title: Oklahoma! (1955)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sunny melodies and open-sky romance carried me along with ease.

simulated_ratings.title: Victor/Victoria (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever, sparkling, and big-hearted, it’s irresistible entertainment.

simulated_ratings.title: Ruby in Paradise (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A quiet, observant journey of self-reinvention that felt honest and humane.

simulated_ratings.title: Vanya on 42nd Street (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stripped-down and intimate, the performances bloomed into something quietly profound.

simulated_ratings.title: Bringing Up Baby (1938)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gloriously madcap screwball that had me laughing start to finish.

simulated_ratings.title: That Darn Cat! (1965)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A light, playful caper with a cozy nostalgic glow.

simulated_ratings.title: Cage aux Folles II, La (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An amiable, lightly farcical romp with enough chuckles to satisfy.
